This video is talking about a topic that I think provides good evidence for God's handiwork in nature. Engineers and computer scientists taking inspiration from nature doesn't seem to fit well in an evolutionary paradigm, but it makes perfect sense in a creation model. You wouldn't expect the selection of random mutations to make algorithms, but an intelligent supernatural Creator [God] would put those algorithms in there with no problem. So why do you people pretend like this obvious sign of a Creator doesn't point to a Creator? That's the flaw of methodological naturalism. Atheists love to pretend like God doesn't exist, even when the evidence of His existence stares them in their faces. Now think about that and learn something.

The hagfish made me think about something. No we don't eat food to our skin, we do consume certain things that way. If a person has a stomach sensitivity to certain medications, they will be given a patch with set medication. I use a CBD ointment for pain, mainly because my work has certain restrictions, and I can't afford to have it in my bloodstream. However the therapeutic factor is able to reach my muscle through the skin. Our bodies expel over 20% of our waste through our pores. As dr. House said, that sounds like a lot. But people who need hormone treatments will often use an ointment instead of a pill because of the absorption ability. Perhaps this is a holdover from when we were able to eat through our skin. If it is, I think we owe the hagfish a debt of gratitude for reminding us.

The proper term for these sub-optimal algorithms inspired by nature is Metaheuristics. They mostly provide good non-deterministic (not ways the same) solution to NP-hard problems. The classics that were left out are Simulated Annealing, Genetic Algorithms, Ant Colony Optimization and Differential Evolution. However, some algorithms such as Simulated Annealing which is a varianty of Metropolis Hastings algorithm do also draw from Statistical Mechanics.

Another relatively simple algorithm that is derived from nature is the 'genetic algorithm' which is inspired by the process of natural selection. It is used to find good solutions for optimization problems by changing parameters of a value through random mutation and crossing over events and finally getting rid of the worst ones.
(Also a big plus is the random survival of some of the less good values, so the algorithm has a chance to search outside of the local optimum)
